abstract: Acquisition of biomedical signals such as photoplethysmogram (PPG) requires Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADCs) that achieve both low power consumption and high efficiency. This research aims to address this challenge by designing a 10-bit monotonic SAR-ADC that utilizes an open-loop voltagecontrolled delay-line time-domain comparator using open-source tools and SkyWater 130 nm PDK. This comparator topology was selected for its proven power efficiency, as prior studies have demonstrated consumption in the microwatt range. This study resulted in a tape-out-ready design of a 10 -bit monotonic SARADC based on a time-domain comparator. Post-layout simulation results demonstrate a power consumption of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$23.25 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex>, achieving an ENOB of 6.44 bits, a DNL of [−1.0, +4.0] LSB, and an INL of [−3.0,+3.0] LSB. Furthermore, the PPG signal acquisition demonstrates high reliability, with an Interclass Correlation Coefficient (ICC) of 0.9939.

title: Adaptive Q-Learning for Robust Navigation in Dynamic 2D Environments for Indian Warehouse Automation
authors: Pancham Singh, Anushka Tyagi, Vimlesh Mishra, Siddhant Gupta, Sahil Bajaj, Rishit Nigam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: In this article, an improved Q-learning framework is proposed for robots to navigate autonomously on a $\mathbf{1 0 x} \mathbf{1 0}$ grid with dynamic obstacles, suited to the ${\$}$200 billion e-commerce industry of India's warehouse automation. The novel techniques proposed are adaptive reward scaling with obstacle density, performance-based dynamic epsilon reduction, and transfer learning for scenarios adapted to the ‘Bengaluru setting.' Our approach, modeled as an MDP, shows an 8% improvement in success rate and 12% in episode reward compared to Q-learning on 2.4 GHz computers in 15,000 episodes. The proposed ‘Warehouse Environment with Variable Speed Obstacles' achieves a success rate of 90 %, viable for low-cost robots. The 1 MB ‘Warehouse Environment’ improves the robustness of robot navigation and is scalable, answering India’s demand for low-cost automation.

title: A Capacitor-Less LDO with Enhanced Wide Band Power Supply Rejection for Voltage-Controlled Oscillator
authors: Chengcheng Zhou, Jiawen Yang, Rui Li, Yongsheng Yin, Xu Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This work proposes a capacitor-less low-dropout regulator (LDO) based on super source follower (SSF) architecture in a 180nm process achieving improved wide band power supply rejection (PSR) performance and fast transient response. With a novel topology that couples the LDO and a symmetric-load voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) with bias, part of the bias circuit proportional to the oscillation intensity flows into the LDO, optimizing the LDO's PSR performance in the mid-to-low frequency. This work is implemented in a 180nm CMOS process. Simulation results demonstrate that incorporating the additional LDO current improves mid-to-low frequency PSR by at least 10dB compared to the condition without the current. Furthermore, the PSR performance remains −28dB at frequencies up to 10GHz, indicating robust PSR performance within wide band. The system takes 37ns to jump from zero load to 20mA full load, with a 210mV overshoot.

title: Relevance-Guided Retrieval under Continually Expanding Knowledge Bases
authors: Hyundong Jin, Heayoun Choi, Eunwoo Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) enhances large language models by incorporating external knowledge to support responses in information-intensive tasks. As knowledge bases expand to accommodate emerging concepts and domains, existing approaches that apply flat retrieval over the entire corpus encounter substantial limitations in efficiency and relevance. To address these challenges, we propose a retrieval method that structures the knowledge base into semantically coherent subsets and confines retrieval to the most relevant subset for each query. This hierarchical procedure enables scalable retrieval under continual expansion of the knowledge base by reducing search space and mitigating irrelevant matches. Experimental results on knowledge-intensive benchmarks show that the proposed method consistently improves both retrieval accuracy and computational efficiency, providing a practical approach to retrieval-augmented generation in expanding knowledge bases.

title: Characterization of a 300 GHz Carrier Wave Using an On-Chip Silicon Electro-Optic-Modulation Comb
authors: Yasunori Yoshida, Rai Kou, Guangwei Cong, Haruki Yaguchi, Mitsuki Nakamura, Tatsuto Okubo, Xuejun Xu, Kenichi Hitachi, Junia Nomura, Noritsugu Yamamoto, Katsuya Oguri, Koji Yamada, Atsushi Ishizawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We generated an electro-optic-modulation (EO) comb using an on-chip silicon modulator. Using this comb, we generated and detected a 300-GHz carrier wave through photodetection, achieving a signal-to-noise ratio of 30 dB. We also evaluated the phase noise and confirmed that it is comparable to that of conventional lithium niobate modulators.

title: Implementation and Analysis of Mandarin Lipreading on Edge Devices
authors: Yu-Hsuan Tseng, Che-Min Tsai, Chong-Hao Xu, Shang-Jang Ruan
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Speech recognition technology is becoming popular in daily life, but it still lacks accuracy in some situations due to noise or environmental noise interference. Thus, lipreading methods based on visual signals can be used in noisy environments or as a communication aid for individuals with hearing impairments, becoming another viable option. However, lipreading models usually involve high computational complexity, making their real-time deployment on resourceconstrained embedded devices challenging. This study proposes a Mandarin lipreading recognition model and deploys it on an edge computing platform equipped with a commercially available AI accelerator evaluating the inference performance and latency in real-world scenarios. The model is trained on the DMCLR Mandarin lipreading dataset and uses a lightweight architecture design, making it suitable for resource-constrained devices. The experimental platform utilizes a Raspberry Pi 5 and is tested with either a Google Coral Edge TPU or a Hailo-8 accelerator. The study compares the differences between the two accelerators in terms of inference speed, accuracy, and temporal task processing capabilities and analyzes their limitations. The results show that both accelerators can support real-time inference, with Hailo-8 exhibiting lower latency and higher accuracy, although model conversion and deployment are more complex. This study demonstrates the feasibility of deploying a lipreading recognition model on edge devices and provides practical insights into the selection of accelerators.

title: Cuffless Blood Pressure Estimation Using Wearable Devices Based on Attention Mechanisms and Synthetic Data From Generative Models
authors: Che-An Chen, Chuan-En Chou, Pei-Yun Tsai, Tzung-Dau Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This study proposes a cuffless and calibration-free blood pressure (BP) estimation method derived from finger photoplethysmography (PPG) and electrocardiography (ECG). A deep learning model based on an intra-cycle attention mechanism was employed using the PPG waveform and handcrafted features, which were mainly derived from weighted pulse decomposition. Distillation was adopted to compress features and to increase generalization and stability. The AAMIcompliant data using mercury sphygmomanometer as the reference were collected. A generative model was established to synthesize PPG waveforms and to mitigate the age bias in our training dataset. Secondary regression was employed to enhance the SBP estimation through synthetic data augmentation. A total of 255 measurements from 85 subjects with a subject-split criterion were tested according to AAMI validation protocol. Experimental results show that the mean and standard deviation of estimation errors for systolic BP were <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.78 \pm \mathbf{8. 7 2 ~ m m H g}$</tex>.

title: Channel-adaptive random access for LEO satellite communication
authors: Jihoon Lee, Gun-Goo Lee, Joon-Gyu Ryu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this paper, the performance of Channel-Adaptive Random Access (CARA) was investigated in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) communication systems. The simulation results show that the performance improvements can be achieved with CARA compared to conventional random access.

title: Quantum-Cryptography Embedded Fault-Tolerant Algorithm for High-Performance Cloud Supercomputing Systems
authors: Saroj Ghimire, Omar Farooque Khan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The necessity for extremely dependable and secure computational infrastructures that can manage large data processing workloads has increased due to the development of cloud-based supercomputing. However, current fault-tolerant systems frequently fail to maintain performance consistency under complicated fault conditions and are not resilient against cyber-attacks at the quantum level. In order to tackle this issue, the research presents a Quantum-Cryptography Embedded Fault-Tolerant Algorithm (QCE-FTA) that incorporates quantum error correction and quantum key distribution (QKD) into the work scheduling and checkpointing layers of cloud supercomputing systems. Without sacrificing processing speed, QCE-FTA guarantees encrypted data transfer, dynamic fault recovery, and secure key exchange. When compared to conventional techniques, experimental simulations conducted on hybrid cloud settings show notable gains in task recovery efficiency, encryption strength, and system stability. According to the results, QCE-FTA offers a scalable, quantum-resilient framework that guarantees data integrity and business continuity for upcoming high-performance cloud infrastructures.

title: Leveraging Machine Learning for Early Detection of Depression Based on Social Media Behavior
authors: Jonathan, Andien Dwi Novika, Derwin Suhartono
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: This research focuses on detecting depression from text based on machine learning algorithms. Depression is a mood disorder that negatively affects one's well-being. With the increase in depression cases worldwide, this research aims to develop an efficient method of detecting depression symptoms based on the words people post on social media. The research uses a dataset of raw text that involves cleaning phases, tokenization, and vectorization. Six machine learning algorithms are used to compare the performance of the algorithms in symptom detection of depression. They are Support Vector Machine, K Nearest Neighbors, Naïve Bayes, Decision Tree, Random Forest, and Neural Network. The result of the research is used for comparison of the accuracy and efficiency levels of each of the algorithms. Experiment outcomes indicate that the Support Vector Machine model achieves the best result, with 0.910 accuracy, establishing its capability for detecting depression. The paper is highly useful for suicide prevention drives, mental health improvement, and provides a technical approach for the detection of symptoms of depression using social media text analysis.

title: Making Pose Representations More Expressive and Disentangled via Residual Vector Quantization
authors: Sukhyun Jeong, Hong-Gi Shin, Yong-Hoon Choi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Recent progress in text-to-motion has advanced both 3D human motion generation and text-based motion control. Controllable motion generation (CoMo), which enables intuitive control, typically relies on pose code representations; however, discrete pose codes alone cannot capture fine-grained motion details, limiting expressiveness. To address this limitation, we propose a method that augments pose code–based latent representations with continuous motion features using residual vector quantization (RVQ). This approach preserves the interpretability and manipulability of pose codes while effectively capturing subtle motion characteristics such as high-frequency details. Experiments on the HumanML3D dataset show that our model reduces the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) from 0.041 to 0.015 and yields a slight improvement in Top-1 R-Precision from 0.508 to 0.510. Qualitative analysis of pairwise direction similarity between pose codes further demonstrates the model’s controllability for motion editing.

title: AI-Driven Simulation and Digital Twin Technologies for Smart Business Planning
authors: Mayank R. Kothawade, Krishan Tuli, Arun Kumar, Veena Hada, Vinay Kumar Singh, Meenakshi Sharma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This research paper explores the intersections between AI-based simulation and digital twin technologies to make intelligent business plans in intelligent business predictive maintenance, process optimization, and decision-making. The concept of a digital twin is developed on four machine learning models, namely- Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Artificial Neural Network (ANN), and gradual Boosting Machine (GBM) trained on a data set consisting of real-time and historical data of IoT connected industrial equipment such as CNC milling machines. The data include sensor measurements, SCADA data, maintenance data, manufacturing statistics, and environmental data, which are exposed to preprocessing techniques such as noise reduction, missing value filling, normalizing and feature engineering. The models are analysed based on their performance in terms of precision, recall, F1-score, accuracy, Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) and R2. ANN is the best of the other models with most predictive reliability and accuracy and has highest operations cost saving (22.7) and energy savings (25.6). GBM comes second as it is dependent on boosting mechanisms to make better predictions. RF has the most favorable trade-off between level of accuracy and efficiency. SVM has the worst performance since it is very sensitive to hyperparameter tuning and non-linearity. The findings determine the capabilities of AI-based digital twins to minimize downtime, decrease maintenance costs, and improve industrial processes. The analysis reveals that ANN can be the most suitable model of predictive analytics and business intelligence that are provided in real-time and, therefore, AI-based digital twins are the valuable instrument of industrial automation in the future. The next round of research might explore the field of hybrid AI methods to improve predictive capability and efficiency in smart manufacturing and optimization of business processes.

title: A Multi-connectivity Scheme for Service Continuity Between Terrestrial and Non-Terrestrial Networks
authors: Yousun Hwang, Sung-Min Oh
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes a dual steering framework that enables user equipment (UE) to maintain seamless service continuity across integrated terrestrial (TN) and non-terrestrial networks (NTN). The proposed approach introduces controlplane procedures for parallel registration, unified PDU session establishment, and dynamic multi-path management between TN and NTN domains. These procedures significantly reduce signaling overhead and enable efficient dual-access connectivity, allowing uninterrupted service delivery even under fluctuating radio conditions and mobility events. This work presents the conceptual framework and procedural design as a foundation for future implementation and performance evaluation.

title: Student Engagement Recognition Using a Hyena-Based Vision Transformer
authors: Liang-Ying Ke, Tzu-Chun Pu, Chih-Hsien Hsia
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: With the advancement of digital learning and the proliferation of e-learning platforms, accurately assessing student engagement has become an essential challenge. However, most existing studies lack the ability to capture global features, making it difficult for deep learning (DL) models to learn the relationships between local features, which in turn limits the effectiveness of feature representation. To address the above-mentioned issues, this paper proposes a vision transformer (ViT) that incorporates Hyena module for student engagement recognition. The Hyena module not only can capture long-range dependencies (LRD) within images, but also possesses the inductive bias of convolutional neural networks (CNNs). These advantages enable the DL model to converge stably on a limited database and effectively enhance its feature representation capability. According to the experimental results, the method proposed by this paper achieved a recall of 83.05 %, a precision of 84.15 %, and an F1-score 83.58 % on the SVD-OL database.

title: Self Heating Aware Temperature Analysis of Hetero Dielectric Vertically Stacked FeFinFET for Digital Circuit Applications
authors: Kajal Verma, Rishu Chaujar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This paper investigates the thermal impact on the analog and linearity performance of Hetero Dielectric Vertically Stacked Ferroelectric FinFET (HD-VS-FeFinFET), integrating advanced technologies like SOI, strained tri-layered channel, and ferroelectric material for improved gate control. It examines how temperature fluctuations can significantly affect device performance in terms of drain current. Also, the device exhibits a Zero Temperature Coefficient (ZTC) point at a gate voltage of 0.5 V, where the drain current remains stable across temperatures. Further, with reduction in peak <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{g}_{\mathrm{m} 2}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{g}_{\mathrm{m} 3}$</tex> by 23.7% and 46.5% respectively along with 14.9% enhancement in 1 dB compression point at 400 K shows its improved linearity performance with rising temperature. Further, device self-heating effects (SHEs) in nonplanar transistors have become a serious issue in designing well-tempered CMOS devices for future logic nodes. So, this work examines the influence of self-heating Effects (SHEs) on the input and output characteristics of the device. Proceeding with the basic parameters of HD-VS-FeFinFET, the authors show the digital applications with the implementation of HD-VS-FeFinFET based CMOS inverter. These insights not only advance the understanding of the device but also affirm the suitability of HD-VS-FeFinFET for nextgeneration low-power, high-performance digital circuit applications.

title: Exponential Hybrid Gannet Bald Leader Optimization Based LeNet Enabled Human Behavior Analysis with Dermatoglyphics Fingerprint Pattern Classification
authors: Mokal Atul Bhimrao, Brijendra Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Fingerprint pattern classification and recognition can be beneficial for the researches on human behavior analysis. In few prior researches, fingerprints are categorized into four types for boosting recognition, even though these classification methods are not appropriate for making research on variety of the human personalities. Here, Exponential Hybrid Gannet Bald Leader Optimization based LeNet (EHGBLO_LeNet) is presented for dermatoglyphics fingerprint pattern classification. Initially, fingerprint image is pre-processed using Gaussian filter. Next, minutiae feature as well as texture feature is extracted. Thereafter, fingerprint pattern is classified using LeNet and it is tuned using Exponential Hybrid Gannet Bald Leader Optimization (EHGBLO). EHGBLO is modeled by incorporating Exponential Weighted Moving Average (EWMA) with Hybrid Gannet Bald Leader Optimization (HGBLO). Furthermore, HGBLO is designed by combining Hybrid Leader-Based Optimization (HLBO) and Gannet Bald Optimization (GBO). Finally, human behavior recognition is accomplished based on classified fingerprint patterns. Moreover, EHGBLO_LeNet achieved accuracy about 93.759%, False Negative Rate (FNR) about 6.241 %, Negative Predictive Value (NPV) about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1. 5 4 1 \%}$</tex>, Positive Predictive Value (PPV) about 92.345 %, True Negative Rate (TNR) of 94.257 % and True Positive Rate (TPR) of 92.531%.

title: Multimodal Knowledge Tracing and Reinforcement Learning for English Learning System
authors: Beili Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: With the rapid development of artificial intelligence in education, personalized learning systems have become increasingly important for English language acquisition. Traditional English learning platforms often rely on single-modal data and lack adaptive learning path optimization, which limits their effectiveness in addressing diverse learner needs. This paper proposes a novel framework that integrates multimodal knowledge tracing with reinforcement learning to build an intelligent English learning system. The proposed method fuses textual, audio, and behavioral data through attention mechanisms, employs a deep knowledge tracing network enhanced with knowledge graph embeddings to model learners' evolving knowledge states, and utilizes deep reinforcement learning algorithms to optimize personalized learning paths dynamically. Comprehensive experiments on benchmark educational datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves superior performance with AUC of 0.86 and ACC of 0.84, significantly outperforming five baseline methods including traditional machine learning approaches and state-of-the-art deep learning techniques. The results validate the effectiveness of multimodal data integration and reinforcement learning-based path optimization in enhancing learning outcomes.

title: Research on Digital Image Protection and AI-Enabled Living Intangible Cultural Heritage of the Jin-style filigree mosaic art based on Schema Theory
authors: Manyu Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: As times progress, the systematic protection and innovative development of Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH) have garnered significant social attention. This study investigates the protection and inheritance strategies for the Jin-style filigree mosaic art, an ICH, in the digital era, addressing the challenges of cultural identity in a rapidly evolving social context. Grounded in schema theory and integrating digital and artificial intelligence technologies, the study devises specific methods for safeguarding and perpetuating this art form. The research team initially examined the historical background, artistic features, and current state of inheritance of the Jin-style filigree mosaic art. Subsequently, they crafted VR/AR encoding plans and validated their efficacy through experimental trials. By surveying 1,138 students from art schools and amassing data on their satisfaction with VR/AR-based science education, the study performed statistical analyses. The findings revealed that VR/AR technology markedly enhanced students’ overall satisfaction and self-efficacy, thereby furnishing empirical evidence for the digital preservation and living inheritance of ICH skills. This research not only offers theoretical underpinnings and practical approaches for the innovative evolution of the Jin-style filigree mosaic art but also serves as a model for the contemporary protection and promotion of other ICH initiatives. Ultimately, the study bolsters the public’s comprehension and appreciation of local culture while propelling the enduring prosperity and development of traditional culture in an age of globalization.

title: Superimposed Pilot based OTFS Channel Estimation for LEO Satellite Communication System
authors: Jiewen Jiang, Cheng Wang, Songsong Cai, Xi Gong, Kaishi Wang, Weidong Wang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The high-speed relative motion between Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites and terrestrial users induces high Doppler shifts, which disrupt subcarrier orthogonality in Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM), introducing severe intercarrier interference (ICI) and degrading system performance. Using delay Doppler (DD) domain signal mapping, Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation can preserve waveform orthogonality under high Doppler conditions, effectively mitigating ICI through its inherent resistance to time-frequency channel variations. In OTFS systems operating with high Doppler frequency shifts, the core technical challenge lies in the estimation of the channel, which is critically dependent on the pilot design. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel superimposed pilot-based channel estimation method for OTFS systems, which innovatively superimposes pilot and data symbols in the delay-Doppler domain through power-sharing modulation, where the pilot employs constant-envelope design for PAPR control. The proposed solution incorporates fractional Doppler precompensation using phase correction θ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">k,l</inf> to mitigate distortion and the guard-interval suppressed boundary leakage to protect superimposed pilots. It also centralized pilot clustering at (k<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>, 1<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>) to minimize Doppler sensitivity and implements parameter processing in the receiver-side channel estimation algorithm specifically optimized for satellite communication scenarios. Simulation results show that, compared to the traditional constant-amplitude high-power pilot and current single-centerpoint unprotected interval superimposed pilot, this method effectively reduces the peak to average power ratio (PAPR). The normalized mean squared error (NMSE) and bit error rate (BER) of the proposed scheme outperform the benchmark schemes, which are highly applicable to the OTFS system in LEO satellite scenarios.

title: Robust Equivalent Transmit Beamforming Under Random Element Failures: A Stochastic Geometry Approach
authors: Adil Farooq, Hasan Mir, Lutfi Albasha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: Equivalent transmit beamforming (ETB) allows a frequency diverse array to emulate a static beampattern at a chosen spatial location. Existing ETB solutions, however, implicitly assume that all array elements remain operational, while in practice, elements may fail due to various hardware and environmental factors. This work embeds a Bernoulli-thinning model of random element outages into the ETB framework and derives a second-order cone program that provides robust beampattern fidelity under the modeled outages with high statistical confidence. Simulations confirm that the proposed design maintains the desired beampattern mainlobe and deep nulls even in the presence of element failures and demonstrates improved robustness compared to conventional minimum variance designs.

title: An Area-Time Efficient and Generic Accelerator for the Verification of Hash-Based Signature Schemes
authors: Yueqin Dai, Yifeng Song, Zhongfeng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The Leighton-Micali Signature (LMS) and the eXtended Merkle Signature Scheme (XMSS) are two stateful hashbased signature (HBS) schemes standardized by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF). Both of them stand out among post-quantum cryptographic (PQC) algorithms due to their wellstudied security. For verification nodes in edge application scenarios, resource-constrained devices must support multiple signature schemes while minimizing overhead. In this work, we propose an area-time efficient and generic accelerator for LMS and XMSS verification. The computation flows are carefully organized into a series of hash tasks and stored in RAM with a custom data distribution strategy. The hash module is designed with five computation modes to fit into each task. Finally, we complete the verification of both LMS and XMSS signatures by processing all tasks and utilizing three parallel hash modules. The experimental results on FPGA demonstrate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.25 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.14 \times$</tex> acceleration in LMS and XMSS verification operations, respectively, compared to the state-of-the-art architecture that supports both schemes. Additionally, the area-time efficiency improves by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.57 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.89 \times$</tex>, respectively.

title: A Wide Bandwidth TIA with Low Power Consumption for PNN Prototyping
authors: L S S Pavan Kumar Chodisetti, Jen-Yu Li, Pradyumna Vellanki, Yung-Jr Hung, Chua-Chin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a high-speed, low-power transimpedance amplifier (TIA) designed for integration within photonic neural networks (PNNs). The proposed architecture, implemented using the TSMC TN40G process, incorporates an active-feedback TIA core, an inductor-less Balun, a digital DC Offset Calibration (DCOC) loop, and a combination of variable and fixed gain amplifier stages. The design addresses critical challenges in PNN systems, including wide bandwidth, low power consumption and offset sensitivity caused by analog front-end mismatches. Post-layout simulations demonstrate a gain tuning range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$33.2 ~\text{dB} \Omega$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$70.3 ~\text{dB} \Omega$</tex> and a bandwidth of 4.08 GHz, with consistent performance across all PVT corners. The proposed TIA design highlights enhanced bandwidth, power efficiency and enhanced signal fidelity, making it suitable for the PNN system realization.

title: AI-Powered Internet of Things (IoT) for Next-Gen Innovations
authors: Hemalatha Naga Himabindu, Gurajada, Rahul Autade
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: With the increasing complexity of interconnected devices and systems, integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) into Smart Systems is becoming essential. This paper discusses the future of AI-powered Smart Systems, focusing on the evolution and potential of IoTok, an innovative convergence of the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligeance (AI). The paper highlights key advancements in AI-driven IoT systems, addresses the challenges involved, and presents future opportunities for creating more intelligent, autonomous, and efficient smart envi-ronments.

title: Integrated Sensing and Communications (ISAC) for 6G: Foundations, Architectures, and Standards-Aligned Prototyping
authors: Anh-Tien Tran, Thanh Thien-An Dang, Chunghyun Lee, Nhu-Ngoc Dao, Sungrae Cho
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This survey consolidates Integrated Sensing and Communications (ISAC) advances most relevant to 6G deployment. We (i) formalize the Cramér–Rao Bound (CRB)–rate Pareto frontier and its constructive covariance designs for point and extended targets; (ii) review delay–Doppler (OTFS) receiver pipelines that retain ISI/ICI in GLRT/CFAR processing with DD-multiplexing; (iii) compare cooperative multi-static and cell-free architectures with centralized receive filtering; (iv) cover environment reconfiguration via intelligent omni-surfaces (IOS/STAR-RIS) and related reconfigurable hardware; and (v) connect theory to practice through standards-aligned WLAN sensing (IEEE 802.11bf) and ultra-broadband THz prototyping. A pair of comparison tables maps representative works to scenarios and highlights what each adds beyond classical ISAC background (metrics, structures, and constraints). We close with open problems in robustness of frontier operation, scalable DD processing, synchronization/fronthaul for cooperation, EM-accurate surface models, and implementation aspects of full-duplex transceivers.

title: ProdSI-ML: A Hybrid Data-Driven Framework for Product Sustainability Evaluation and Predictive Modeling in Consumer Electronics
authors: Swasti Singhal, Laxmi Ahuja, Abhinav Juneja
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The dynamic pace at which products are innovated, especially the consumer electronics, is changing the world industries. As the corporations focus on improving the quality of life by developing new products all the time, matters become more complex in balancing the variety of the product lines with the requirement to act in harmony with the sustainability requirements. Maintaining the balance between innovation, productivity and environmental stewardship is also a major issue and particularly in high turnover industries like the smartphones, where life cycle is also short and competition is very high making issues of ecology and social responsibility more prominent. This paper introduces a hybrid Product Sustainability Index (ProdSI) model that combines the use of Fuzzy-AHP and Entropy weighting with the machine learning (ML) technologies to compare and forecast the sustainability and pricing of flagship smartphones: Apple iPhone 15 Pro and Samsung Galaxy S23 Ultra. Forty-three indicators, in relation to environmental, social, and economic spheres, were evaluated. The results of the experiments prove the higher sustainability of iPhone 15 Pro which attended the higher normalized ProdSI score as it is better performing in the aspects of energy efficiency, recyclability, and social compliance. XGBoost, of the models tested, had a prediction accuracy of 95% compared to the traditional regression models and feature importance and scatter plot analysis revealed the heavy dependence of sustainability measures on predicting prices. The results demonstrate that not only data-driven benchmarking is supported by ML-driven sustainability assessment, but also cost optimization, anomaly detection, and enhanced strategies of developing products. This publication shows how responsible innovation, which is based on intelligent analytics, can balance environmental goals with industry competitiveness and support the development of ecosystems of sustainable product development.

title: A Ka-Band Variable-Gain Phase Shifter for 6G NTN with LEO Satellites
authors: Mingyu Lee, Wonseob Lee, Hyeonwon Song, Hyungju Kim, Seunghyun Jang, Hui-Dong Lee, Bonghyuk Park, Seungchan Lee, Jinseok Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: A Ka-band variable-gain phase shifter (VGPS) for 6G non-terrestrial networks with low Earth orbit satellites is presented. The VGPS consists of a two-stage IQ generator and a vector generator. The 2-stage IQ generator includes a hybrid coupler and a single-stage RC poly-phase filter to ensure high accuracy. The vector generator is implemented using a Gilbert-cell-based vector summing structure. The VGPS was integrated into a transmitter front-end integrated circuit. Simulated gain of VGPS is -2.4 dB at 33 GHz, with a 3-dB bandwidth ranging from 29.5 to 38.5 GHz. Measured RMS phase and gain errors at 29 GHz were 0.36° and 0.059 dB, respectively.

title: Multi-modal Causal RAG for Aviation Accident Analysis and Risk Prediction
authors: Morsheda Akter, Yang Cao, Chung-Horng Lung
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Aviation safety analysis has traditionally relied on structured reports and expert-driven causal reasoning. Under-standing aviation accident requires a holistic approach that integrates multi-modal data, including textual reports, images, and structured knowledge representations. This paper proposes a novel multi-modal retrieval and analysis framework that integrates Natural Language Processing (NLP), Causal Relation Extraction, CLIP-based image embedding, and Latent Con-textual Modeling (LCM) with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to link textual and visual aviation accident evidence. The system enables users to upload new incident images, such as those from newspapers or social media, and automatically match them with similar historical accidents, revealing causes and contributing factors through generative explanation. This pipeline demonstrates the feasibility of a next-generation decision-support tool for aviation safety that is interpretable, context-aware, and multi-modal. Experimental results demonstrate that our model effectively identifies and aligns latent representations across modalities, while the LLM generates coherent, contextually grounded explanations.

title: Multidimensional Model for Measuring Knowledge Generation in Higher Education through Artificial Intelligence and Pedagogical Mediation
authors: María-Stefanie Vásquez-Peñafiel, Patricio Andino-Sosa, Paulina Vizcaino, Jesenia Verdezoto Camacho, Martina Jaramillo-Cerda
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: In the current educational context, the widespread use of artificial intelligence (AI) has transformed how students access, process, and produce information. However, concerns have emerged regarding the extent to which AI facilitates the genuine generation of knowledge versus superficial task completion. This article presents the design and initial validation of a comprehensive model to measure knowledge generation in higher education, emphasizing the role of pedagogical mediation and the responsible integration of AI tools. The model is built on four interrelated dimensions: pedagogical mediation, use of AI, infrastructure and access to resources, and motivation in AI use. Each dimension includes key variables and indicators derived from a literature review and expert validation. Data were collected through surveys administered to 20 professors and 330 students who participated in AI-integrated courses after teacher training workshops. Preliminary descriptive results show that students felt more motivated to learn autonomously and perceived that AI tools helped them better understand content. The model offers a novel, structured approach to assess whether knowledge is truly being generated through AI-enhanced learning, setting the groundwork for further analysis using fuzzy-set Qualitative Comparative Analysis (fsQCA).

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Bitrate Streaming over Wireless Networks: Advances, Challenges, and Open-Source Simulation
authors: Thanh Thien-An Dang, Anh-Tien Tran, Nhu-Ngoc Dao, Sungrae Cho
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Adaptive Bitrate (ABR) streaming is the de facto mechanism for delivering video over heterogeneous and time-varying wireless networks. However, volatile bandwidth, interference, mobility, and resource contention complicate bitrate selection and buffer control, often degrading users’ Quality of Experience (QoE). Traditional rule-based ABR algorithms struggle to generalize across diverse conditions. Recent work demonstrates that Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) can jointly reason over network dynamics and player status to optimize QoE, including quality, rebuffering, smoothness, and latency. This paper surveys DRL-based ABR advances from 2022 to 2025 in wireless contexts and emphasizes the role of open and reproducible research using ns-3 for network simulation and FFmpeg for video processing and objective quality assessment (e.g., PSNR, SSIM, VMAF). We first formalize the DRL problem for ABR (state, action, and reward design), then discuss how ns-3 models cellular and Wi-Fi environments and how FFmpeg enables practical bitrate ladders, decoding, trace generation, and automated quality evaluation. We synthesize findings across recent works on access-point-assisted ABR, meta-RL bitrate guidance, cross-layer optimization for real-time communication, fairness-aware multiuser bandwidth allocation at the mobile edge, and throughput prediction for ABR. We highlight reported gains, modeling choices, and, critically, open-source availability where indicated. We conclude by outlining open challenges—generalization, QoE modeling, and real-world deployment—and advocating for open-source benchmarks, datasets, and truly end-to-end ns-3+FFmpeg pipelines to accelerate impactful and reproducible research in DRL-driven ABR for wireless video streaming.

title: Research on the Melting Mechanism and Prevention Measures of PT High Voltage Fuses in 10∼35KV Distribution Networks
authors: Fanggang Xu, Mingyu Jing, Jingjing Du, Rui Li, Bo Sun, Xianguang Che, Ejuan Zhou, Wei Liu, Xianpeng Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: At present, China's 10-35kV distribution network often adopts a neutral ungrounded system. In the neutral ungrounded system of 10-35kV, the frequent melting of the high-voltage fuse of the potential transformer (PT) seriously affects the safe and reliable operation of the system. To solve this problem, the common reasons for frequent melting of PT high-voltage fuses were first studied and summarized; Secondly, theoretical analysis is conducted on the melting mechanism of PT high-voltage fuses; Then, the PSCAD simulation software was used to model and simulate the ferromagnetic resonance circuit of the PT high-voltage fuse in the 10 kV neutral point ungrounded system; Finally, summarize and propose preventive measures for frequent melting of PT high-voltage fuses, and verify the effectiveness of the proposed measures through simulation.

title: Integrated RTBH-RBS Model for Illegal Traffic Mitigation in Indonesia's Internet Exchange
authors: Muhammad Arif, Charles Lim, Mohammad A. Amin Soetomo, Eka Budiarto
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The Indonesia Internet Exchange (IIX) requires mitigation mechanisms that are both scalable and policy-compliant to address illegal traffic such as gambling, phishing, and DDoS. This paper proposes an integrated framework combining Remotely Triggered Black Hole (RTBH) filtering with a Rule-Based System (RBS) to pair upstream packet discard with deterministic, auditable policy logic. We present the system architecture, a PASTA-inspired threat model, five operational threat scenarios with controls, and a deployment risk matrix. We also detail a lightweight testbed methodology—covering detection-to-mitigation latency, false-positive ratio, and blackhole scope impact—to guide empirical validation at IIX and multi-ISP pilots. The blueprint emphasizes staged blackholing, strict access governance, and transparent rollback to minimize collateral impact while aligning with Indonesian regulations.

title: A Comparative Study of ETS and ARIMA Algorithms for Forecasting Indonesia's Rice Export and Import
authors: Nurul Fajriah Pinem e, Dian Rachmawati, Dian Pebriyani, Muhammad Haikal Rahman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: This study presents the development of a web-based forecasting application to analyze Indonesia's rice import and export data from 1990 to 2024 using ARIMA and ETS time-series models. The system implements automatic model selection and logarithmic transformation to handle variance instability and nonstationary patterns in trade data. Comparative analysis shows that the ARIMA model consistently outperforms ETS in terms of MAPE, particularly for monetary variables, while ETS occasionally provides lower MAE and RMSE values for smoother time-series data. The evaluation revealed that both models faced challenges in accurately forecasting highvariance export quantities. Despite this, ARIMA demonstrates better adaptability to complex economic patterns and serves as a reliable baseline for short- and medium-term forecasting. The application is deployed via an interactive Gradio interface, making advanced forecasting tools accessible to non-technical stakeholders, such as policymakers and trade planners. Future work will explore hybrid and multivariate approaches to enhance the predictive performance by incorporating external economic and environmental factors.

title: GestOS: Advanced Hand Gesture Interpretation via Large Language Models to control Any Type of Robot
authors: Artem Lykov, Oleg Kobzarev, Dzmitry Tsetserukou
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: We present GestOS, a gesture-based Operating System for a high-level control of heterogeneous robot teams. Unlike prior systems that map gestures to fixed commands or single-agent actions, GestOS interprets hand gestures semantically and dynamically distributes tasks across multiple robots based on their capabilities, current state, and supported instruction sets. The system combines lightweight visual perception with Large Language Model (LLM) reasoning: hand poses are converted into the structured textual descriptions, which LLM uses to infer intent and generate robot-specific commands. A robot selection module ensures that each gesture-triggered task is matched to the most suitable agent in real time. This architecture enables context-aware, adaptive control without requiring explicit user specification of targets or commands. By advancing gesture interaction from recognition to intelligent orchestration, GestOS supports scalable, flexible, and user-friendly collaboration with robotic systems in dynamic environments.

title: Active RIS-aided NOMA-ISAC Network Architecture for LEO Satellite Communications
authors: Soumen Mondal, Keshav Singh, Chih-Peng Li, Zhiguo Ding
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper analyzes the performance of a non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA)-enabled, active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system operating within a non-terrestrial network (NTN) framework. The end-to-end equivalent channel under maximum ratio transmission (MRT) beamforming is de-rived and modeled as a Gamma distribution. A closed-form expression for the outage probability (OP) is obtained in terms of Meijer G-functions, and the analytical findings are validated via Monte Carlo simulations. To further characterize system performance, the asymptotic expression of the OP and the associated diversity order are also derived. The effectiveness of the active RIS in mitigating multiplicative fading through signal amplification is evaluated by comparison with a conventional passive RIS scheme, revealing substantial performance improvements. Moreover, the impact of hardware impairments and channel shadowing is examined. On the sensing side, the proposed ISAC system is compared with a traditional radar in terms of beampattern gain.

title: Design and Implementation of an Inline Array Architecture for Variational Autoencoders Accelerator
authors: Raphael Wiswa Santoso Samosir, Teuku Muhammad Roffi, Ade Irawan
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: As data continues to expand rapidly, the Variational Autoencoder (VAE) has become an essential tool for data compression, representation learning, and the creation of synthetic data. By applying a probabilistic mapping into a latent distribution, it is able to reconstruct inputs and produce new variations. However, VAE implementations on Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) remain limited, especially for the MNIST dataset, indicating the gap to explore optimal and efficient hardware architectures. This research designs and develops an integrated circuit for the encoder block of a VAE on an FPGA with minimized inference latency by utilizing an Inline-Array architecture. A semi-parallel architecture was used as the baseline. Implementation on the Kria KV260 FPGA with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28 \times 28$</tex> MNIST input started with a grid search for model setup, followed by RTL synthesis and verification using a testbench and PYNQ. Results show that the Inline-Array reduces latency by approximately 0.0025 seconds compared to the CPU and 0.00076 seconds compared to the Semi-Parallel approach, lowers power consumption by 3.95 %, and optimizes resource utilization through an adder tree design. The reconstruction accuracy was generally the same as CPU and Semi-Parallel results, except for digit “2,” which produced a larger error because of fixed-point quantization overflow. These results show that the Inline-Array has good potential as a low-power and low-latency VAE accelerator for edge computing applications.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization of Fractional Order Controllers for Three Area Load Frequency Regulation
authors: Shubra Goel, Omveer Singh, D.K. P Singh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This study introduces a hybrid control strategy combining Fuzzy FOPI and TID controllers to address frequency regulation challenges in multi-area power systems with high renewable energy penetration. The test system considered comprises three interconnected areas incorporating gas turbines, wind energy units, and distributed electric vehicles. By integrating intelligent fuzzy-based FOPI with conventional TID control, the approach achieves enhanced robustness and efficiency in load frequency management. Controller parameters are fine-tuned using the TeachingLearning Based Optimization (TLBO) algorithm, a modern metaheuristic technique. The proposed hybrid controller is evaluated under diverse operating conditions, including demand fluctuations and renewable intermittency. Simulation outcomes highlight its superior capability in sustaining frequency stability compared to traditional control methods.

title: Chaotic Enhancement via LE-guided Quantum XYZ Rotational Encoding and Amplitude-Scaled
authors: De Rosal Ignatius Moses Setiadi, Supriadi Rustad, T. Sutojo, Muhamad Akrom, Mohamad Afendee Mohamed, Aceng Sambas
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The security of chaos-based cryptography depends on the quality of the chaotic sequences used as keystreams. However, conventional chaotic systems often suffer from limitations in entropy, sensitivity to initial conditions, and the quality of randomness. This study proposes an enhancement method based on Lyapunov Exponent (LE)-guided quantum XYZ rotational encoding applied to Lorenz, Chen, and Rossler systems. The chaotic sequences are further amplified using a single-qubit quantum circuit with Hadamard, RX, RY, and RZ rotations. The evaluation conducted before (classic) and after the transformation (quantum) includes key aspects: LE, Shannon entropy, autocorrelation, bifurcation diagram, trajectories, and NIST SP 800-22 statistical testing. To ensure robust statistical assessment, the chaotic sequences were generated using a Multiple-Run Strategy with varying initial conditions to construct bitstreams suitable for NIST analysis. The results demonstrate significant improvements: LE increased up to tenfold, entropy values approached theoretical limits, autocorrelation decreased notably, and all sequences successfully passed the NIST tests under recommended parameters. These findings affirm the potential of LE-guided quantum rotations as an effective strategy for enhancing chaotic dynamics and improving the statistical security of cryptography keystreams.

title: A Behavior-Aware Identity and Access Monitoring Framework for Securing Outsourced Data in Cloud Environments
authors: Thirumalai Selvan C, Gayathri Parasa, Puneet Sharma, C Ambhika Chinnadurai, Ishit Jain, P. Kaushik
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Data outsourcing presents major challenges in the monitoring of unauthorized identities and the access behavior in the modern cloud computing. To resolve this, this study proposes a holistic model in the trustworthy detection of anomalies in the environment of cloud replication, whilst having twofold aims of improving data safety as well as robust surveillance. The suggested solution gathers the information of various sources in a systematic manner, such as user profiles, access logs, and cloud records. By using modern technologies like AWS CloudTrail and Apache Kafka, the data is preprocessed, cleansed, normalized and features extracted. The feature engineering is critical in shaping the user behavior patterns with the consideration of factors like frequency of logins, access patterns of files and system command. In anomaly detection, the framework uses a variety of strategies, such as unsupervised learning algorithms (k-means, isolation forest), statistical approaches, and neural networks (autoencoders, RNNs). Proactive security is provided by real-time notifications, automated reactions and interactive dashboards, and smoothly integrated into Security information and event management frameworks (SIEM). Extensive tests prove the effectiveness of the framework in identifying illegal access and the provision of security teams with practical information. The study provides a sophisticated solution to enhance the security of the cloud and solve identity theft and access control in outsourced data environments.

title: LSTM-Based Destination Prediction Method Using Location Information and Temporal Characteristics
authors: Ji Hwan Jeong, Won Seok Choi, Hyeon Muk Park, Seong Gon Choi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: To reflect personal characteristics in destination recommendations, we propose an LSTM based user destination prediction method that uses the temporal characteristics of user location information. For this purpose, we introduce preprocessing methods for time series GPS data and an LSTM based architecture for user destination prediction. The preprocessing method utilizes GPS records of user location and date related features, applying one-hot encoding and min–max normalization to prepare the inputs for the prediction model. For validation, the proposed pipeline was implemented in Python, and its performance was assessed using the F1-score metric.

title: Counsel - An Artificial Intelligence Powered SaaS for Legal Professionals
authors: Jameer Kotwal, Priyanka Chetwani, Arpeet Jawade, Aditya Singh, Nida Deshmukh, Yashraj Kanake
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: In this paper, we present the Counsel, an AI-based legal assistant developed to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of legal practitioners. Powered by technologies like natural language processing (NLP), machine learning, and information retrieval Counsel can process legal questions, review documents on the fly, and surface actionable insights with tools like named entity recognition (NER) and optical character recognition (OCR). With a proven success rate of 94%, it automates the creation of legal documents like contracts and agreements using custom templates and rule-based logic, cutting hours of manual work, ensuring great consistency and legal grade accuracy. Counsel also uses smart-drafting tools that include context-aware suggestions that help reduce human error, prevent misuse of legal terminology and speed up the creation of better, more concise documents. By automating research and document preparation, Counsel allows lawyers to focus on strategic legal work and client engagement, thereby setting a new benchmark for innovation and productivity in the legal-tech domain.

title: Impact of Metal Oxide Varistor on the Occurrence of Ferroresonance Oscillations in Transformers
authors: Rajat Shubhra Pal, Madhab Roy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The impact of a parallel Metal Oxide Varistor (MOV) on the transformer's ferroresonance oscillations is examined in this paper. It is anticipated that an arrester generally causes ferroresonance mitigation. But for a sustained ferroresonance, sometimes MOV fails to protect the transformer. To investigate this effect, MATLAB SIMULINK has been used for time-domain simulation. A single phase unloaded transformer has been simulated. A two-term polynomial of order seven is used to simulate the transformer's magnetization characteristic. Linear resistance is used to model the core loss. The impact of changing the input voltage has been investigated. MOVs with different characteristics have been taken and the points of breakdown have been found out under sustained ferroresonance. This work can help to choose MOV of proper rating for specific transformer application.

title: Design and Simulation of a Compact UHF Antenna for CubeSat Applications
authors: S. Kanthalakshmi, Thirumalai Raj M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: This paper presents the design and simulation of a compact Ultra High Frequency (UHF) antenna optimized for CubeSat communication systems operating at 398 MHz. CubeSats, due to their small form factor, face significant challenges in antenna design, particularly when balancing performance, size, and deployment mechanisms. The proposed antenna design aims to achieve high directivity and acceptable bandwidth within the limited physical constraints of CubeSats. Simulation results indicate a peak directivity of 1.75 dBi and a radiation pattern that is suitable for low-Earth orbit (LEO) communication scenarios. This work contributes towards developing efficient CubeSat-compatible antennas and provides a basis for future physical prototyping and space qualification.

title: Energy-Efficient ReRAM-Based In-Memory Computing with Dual SNN/ANN Modes
authors: Chang-Yu Kuo, Tian-Sheuan Chang, Tsung-Heng Tsai
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The escalating energy demands of AI computing, driven by data transfers between memory and processing units, necessitate innovative solutions like Computing-in-Memory (CIM). This paper presents a novel ReRAM-based CIM macro that achieves exceptional energy efficiency of 3349.1 1b-TOPS/W at 250 MHz, supporting both Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) for low-power edge applications and Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) for high-precision tasks. We introduce three key innovations: a single-pulse Pulse Width Modulator (PWM) with shared generators reducing wordline driver power by 85% and area by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 1 \%}$</tex>, a dual-slope Voltage-to-Time Converter (VTC) achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6 \%}$</tex> power savings in readout circuits, and an event-based Time-to-Digital Converter (TDC) optimized for high-sparsity SNNs, yielding 90% power reduction. Non-ideal effects, including cell variations and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R C}$</tex> delays, are mitigated through differential architectures, hardware calibration, and non-ideal effects-aware training. Evaluated on the Google Speech Command dataset, our design achieves up to 93.37% keyword spotting accuracy across SNN, ternary ANN, and 4-bit ANN modes, with a 134% energy efficiency improvement over state-of-the-art. This work advances hardware-software co-design for robust, energy-efficient CIM solutions.

title: Energy-Efficient Hybrid Clustering for Wireless Rechargeable Sensor Networks: A Machine Learning Approach Using K-Means and Gaussian Mixture Models
authors: Kumar Dayanand, Udai Shankar, Mohit Kumar, Kumar Arvind
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The potential of Wireless Rechargeable Sensor Networks (WRSNs) to extend the operating lifetime of wireless sensor networks (WSNs) through energy harvesting and replenishment approaches has attracted a lot of attention. However, in order to maximize energy use, minimize communication overhead, and guarantee network stability, an effective clustering mechanism is essential. In this work, we propose a hybrid clustering method to efficiently arrange sensor nodes in a WRSN by combining the Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) with K-Means clustering. K-Means clustering, which swiftly divides sensor nodes into K groups according to their physical closeness and ensures a balanced load distribution among clusters, is the first step in the process. Nevertheless, K-Means’s ability to handle overlapping clusters and distribute nodes probabilistically is limited. In order to improve flexibility in dynamic network environments, we use GMM to optimize the clustering process by taking into account the probabilistic distribution of sensor nodes inside each cluster. More precise and adaptable clustering is produced by iteratively optimizing cluster membership probability using the ExpectationMaximization (EM) algorithm. Key performance indicators like Silhouette Score, energy consumption analysis, and network lifespan estimation are used to evaluate performance and show notable increases in clustering efficiency and energy savings. By offering an effective, flexible, and scalable clustering solution in WRSNs, the suggested hybrid strategy improves resource management and lengthens sensor networks’ lifespan.

title: Seeing the Future (Phase I): AI-Based Measurement Prediction for Reliable High-Capacity Vehicular Connectivity in Road-Embedded Mobile Networks
authors: Soon-Gi Park, Jun-Sik Kim, Kwang-Seon Kim, Young-Jo Ko
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Future vehicles require ultra-reliable, low-latency, and high-capacity wireless connectivity for autonomous driving and entertainment services such as XR. This paper investigates AI-based measurement prediction for proactive handover in road-embedded mobile networks, training models on simulated mobility data to minimize prediction errors. Evaluation across various test cases demonstrates measurement prediction performance and provides generalization guidelines for AI-driven vehicular inter-cell mobility.

title: Scaled Reflection Cross-Section/ISAR Measurement using Photonic IC
authors: Lucio De Pra, Michael Benker, Tariq Manzur, Yifei Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: Characterizing the backscattering properties of complex electromagnetic structures is often limited by the need for large test environments such as anechoic chambers. To address this challenge, we present a photonic integrated circuit (PIC) based wavelength-scaled optical inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) system capable of characterizing millimeter-scale targets using near-infrared light.

title: Comparative Analysis of Different Deepfake Video Detectors
authors: Vaibhav Sharma, Shradha Porwal
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Deepfake technology is advancing and so are its threats, including misinformation, identity theft, digital bullying, etc. To deal with these, numerous algorithms have been developed by various scholars. This report examines some of the most notable, including CNN, Vision Transformers, and Hybrid networks, and analyzes their performance across the FaceForensics++, DFDC, and Celeb-DF datasets. Models such as MesoNet, XceptionNet, EfficientNet, and some ViT varieties are evaluated for their effectiveness as measured by various performance indicators such as accuracy, F1 Score, and AUCROC. The findings especially indicate the greater generalizability and robustness of transformer models on poorer quality data. The report also discusses the challenges and the compromises that have to be made, especially with regards to accuracy and speed in order to have faster models, then makes suggestions for the creation of more robust and scalable models that can be used on a wide variety of deepfake detection tasks. Index Terms-Deepfake Detection, Video Forensics, Convolutional Neural Networks, XceptionNet, Transformers.

title: Distance-Aware Single-Stage Detectors: Combining Detection with Object-Specific Distance Estimation
authors: Jon Hernandez Aranda, Patrick Dominique Vibild, Daeyoung Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Monocular distance estimation enables 3D understanding from single-camera images, supporting navigation and safety applications. We present two RetinaNet-based single-stage models: DistinaNet and DistinaNet-BBoxExt, enhancing the RetinaNet architecture with distance estimation capabilities via ExtraHead and BBoxExtension strategies. Benchmarked on the KITTI dataset, DistinaNet outperforms state-of-the-art object-specific methods by 44.82% in MAE. Ablation studies show that adding the distance estimation task does not degrade detection performance. We also analyze FPN layer contributions, head architectures, and loss functions. Both models demonstrate strong generalization to unseen real-world driving scenarios, validated using data captured from a custom data collection pipeline. Code is available at https://github.com/jonher16/distinanetforreproduction.

title: Design and Construction of a Fall-Mitigation Device for the Elderly
authors: Nigel Bryan Tang, Willy Anugrah Cahyadi, Husneni Mukhtar, Muhammad Fasha Aqillah, Suto Setiyadi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: This paper presents an integrated airbag system designed to mitigate fall-related injuries among the elderly. The solution combines inertial measurement unit (IMU) sensors, machine learning, and real-time emergency response mechanisms within a wearable vest. A 1D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) achieves 100% classification accuracy in distinguishing between STABLE, UNSTABLE, and FALL states, validated through testing with five subjects. The system employs dual XIAO-ESP32S3 microcontrollers for sensor processing and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>-based airbag deployment, complemented by GPS tracking and surroundings capture. A dedicated mobile application delivers fall alerts with location data to caregivers via Firebase, demonstrating an average 3.5-second notification delay in real-world testing. The implementation addresses key challenges in elderly care by providing immediate physical protection during falls while enabling rapid emergency response. Future work will focus on enhancing wearability through component miniaturization and improved ergonomic design.

title: Stereo Vision-Based Skeleton Pose Estimation with Proximity Index for Environment
authors: Sukwoo Jung, Youn-Sung Lee, Jung Wook Wee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Ensuring worker safety requires accurate monitoring of human movement and detection of potential hazards in workplace environments. This study presents a stereo vision-based skeleton pose estimation framework that incorporates a Proximity Index (PI) to evaluate the distance between human body joints and predefined risk zones. Using the ZED 2i stereo camera, both RGB images and depth maps were acquired to enable reliable three-dimensional pose estimation. The proposed method extracts skeleton data from static images, computes a joint-to-zone distance metric, and classifies safety states based on threshold PI values. Unlike conventional 2D pose estimation approaches, the integration of stereo depth information improves accuracy in proximity evaluation and risk detection. To validate the framework, experiments were conducted in a office environment, simulating scenarios where workers approached restricted or hazardous areas. The results confirm that the method effectively detects abnormal proximity behaviors and supports real-time safety monitoring in workplace settings.

title: Design and Implementation of a Multi-Sensor MEMS-Based Flight Data Monitoring and Tracking System Using Hybrid Communication Networks
authors: Mohamed Tarmizi Ahmad, Michael Lam, Amzari Zhahir, Razali Abidin, Baizura Bohari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: The ability to continuously monitor aircraft flight parameters in real time is a crucial enabler for both operational safety and post-incident investigations. This paper presents the design and implementation of an integrated Flight Data Monitoring (FDM) and tracking system based on micro-electromechanical system (MEMS) sensors, multi-sensor fusion algorithms, and hybrid satellite-terrestrial communication protocols. The proposed system incorporates a tri-axis accelerometer, gyroscope, and magnetometer in conjunction with multi-constellation GNSS receivers (GPS/Galileo/GLONASS) to provide high-fidelity position, velocity, and attitude data. An Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) framework is implemented in the embedded microcontroller to fuse inertial and GNSS measurements, thereby reducing drift and improving estimation accuracy. The system utilises a dualmode communication architecture combining GSM/GPRS and Iridium satellite networks, with automatic switching to ensure global coverage and minimal latency. Data is transmitted to a cloud-based fleet management server for real-time visualisation, archival storage, and post-flight analysis. Experimental validation conducted on a Cirrus SR20 aircraft demonstrates an average positional accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 2.5 \mathrm{m}$</tex>, attitude estimation within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1.2^{\circ}$</tex>, and seamless communication switching with a latency of less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 5}$</tex> seconds. The results confirm the viability of the proposed architecture as a low-cost, scalable, and globally deployable FDM solution suitable for both civil and military aviation applications.

title: VALID-Mol: A Systematic Framework for Validated LLM-Assisted Molecular Design
authors: Malikussaid, Hilal Hudan Nuha, Isman Kurniawan
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Large Language Models demonstrate substantial promise for advancing scientific discovery, yet their deployment in disciplines demanding factual precision and specialized domain constraints presents significant challenges. Within molecular design for pharmaceutical development, these models can propose innovative molecular modifications but frequently generate chemically infeasible structures. We introduce VALID-Mol, a comprehensive framework that integrates chemical validation with LLM-driven molecular design, achieving an improvement in valid chemical structure generation from 3% to 83%. Our methodology synthesizes systematic prompt optimization, automated chemical verification, and domain-adapted fine-tuning to ensure dependable generation of synthesizable molecules with enhanced properties. Our contribution extends beyond implementation details to provide a transferable methodology for scientifically-constrained LLM applications with measurable reliability enhancements. Computational analyses indicate our framework generates promising synthesis candidates with up to 17-fold predicted improvements in target binding affinity while preserving synthetic feasibility.

title: Integration of IV Characteristic Spectrum and Infrared Thermal Imaging for Crack Fault Diagnosis in Photovoltaic Modules
authors: Xianghui Xiao, Zirui Luo, Hao Tang, Xiaoliang Yang, Kangtao Yuan
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) module failures, particularly micro-cracks, significantly impact power generation efficiency and module lifespan. Traditional diagnostic methods, such as IV curve analysis and infrared thermal imaging, suffer from limitations including low spatial resolution, environmental interference, and inability to quantify electrical losses. This paper proposes an automated diagnostic method that integrates IV characteristic spectra and infrared thermal imaging for accurate crack localization and electrical loss assessment. A synchronized data acquisition system is developed, along with an environmental compensation model and a dual-channel convolutional neural network (CNN) for feature fusion and fault classification. Experimental results demonstrate a crack localization accuracy of $\leqslant 0.8 \mathrm{~cm}$, a micro-crack detection rate of $96.2 \%$, and a significant improvement in anti-interference capability under varying environmental conditions. The proposed method offers a reliable, automated solution for early-stage crack detection in photovoltaic systems.

title: Dual Point Control with Virtual Sensing Technique in Active Noise Control
authors: Naoyuki Kawashiri, Naoto Sasaoka
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Active noise control using virtual sensing technique can generate a zone of quiet away from the physical microphone to suppress unwanted noise. Conventional virtual sensing techniques aim to suppress noise at the virtual microphone location and cannot reduce noise at the physical microphone location. Therefore, this paper proposes a virtual sensing technique that achieves noise reduction at both virtual and physical microphone locations in a non-causal arrangement. Simulation results show that noise reduction is possible at both the virtual and physical microphone locations. In particular, the noise reduction at the physical microphone location is about 0 dB with the conventional method, whereas it is about −27 dB with the proposed method.

title: Impact of Rainfall on the Wireless Transmission of Signals
authors: Sanjeev Goyal, R. K. Yadav
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Rainfall substantially affects the wireless transmission of the signals, especially the Wi-Fi and internet connections. Power loss of the signals which is caused by rain absorption and scattering of r.f. energy leads to the poor internet speed and/or complete discontinuity. Parameters such as intensity of rainfall, its frequency, distance and obstructions are responsible for the signal attenuation. In this research paper we have studied the effect of rain on various types of internet services e.g. cellular networks, satellite internet and Wi-Fi. Different strategies to overcome the rain’s impact on Wi-Fi e.g. using the weather proof equipments, placing the routers strategically and using the mesh networks are also covered in this paper. We are hopeful that the understanding of these factors can help in maximizing the wireless communication systems and minimizing the disruptions during rainy seasons.

title: Interpretable Detection of Encrypted Traffic Using SHAP-Based Feature Attribution
authors: Jiwon Suh, Juwon Hong, Mose Gu, Jaehoon Paul Jeong
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: With the widespread adoption of encryption, payload-based intrusion detection has become infeasible, leaving a critical gap in identifying malicious activity within encrypted traffic. While machine learning approaches using flow-level metadata have emerged as promising alternatives, their black-box nature prevents analysts from understanding or trusting the results. In this paper, we propose an interpretable framework that not only detects malicious encrypted traffic but also explains why a session is flagged and how operators should respond. Our approach integrates a Random Forest classifier with SHAP (SHapley Additive Explanations) to provide both global insights into model behavior and local, per-session explanations. A domain-aware explanation engine further translates SHAP outputs into semantic interpretations and automated security recommendations, enabling even non-expert operators to understand causes and mitigation strategies. These results are delivered through an interactive dashboard that supports analyst-driven investigation and response. Experiments on a public encrypted traffic dataset demonstrate that our system maintains high detection accuracy (>99%) while bridging the gap between model prediction and human-centered decision-making.

title: Drug Dosage of Immune System Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Winalda Pratiwi, Infall Syafalni, Nana Sutisna, Nur Ahmadi, Trio Adiono
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
