abstract: Chemotherapy requires careful adjustment of drug dosages to reduce tumor volume while preserving immune function and minimizing toxicity. Current fixed-dose regimens lack adaptability to patient-specific tumor and immune dynamics, limiting treatment effectiveness. This study proposes a reinforcement learning (RL) framework based on a biologically informed mathematical model of tumor volume and immune cell density interactions. Using the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm, the RL agent learns continuous drug dosing policies that are validated through simulation of nonlinear tumor growth and immune response under clinical constraints. Results indicate average tumor volume reduction from 0.799 to 0.173, immune cell density improvement from 0.602 to 0.936, and stable, bounded drug dosing consistent with safety limits. Reward progression demonstrates effective balancing of tumor suppression, immune maintenance, and drug toxicity. Our framework also outlines implementation on field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) for possible real-time clinical decision support. These findings suggest RL-based dosing strategies can provide more personalized and adaptive chemotherapy management than standard protocols.

title: Revolutionizing the Electricity Sector with Innovative IoT Solutions
authors: Seema Malik, Rishabh Jain, R K Yadav, Amit Singhal
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Electricity has been radically changed by the emergence of the Internet of Things (IoT). The incorporation of intelligent sensors and interdependent gadgets has made power systems more efficient, reliable, and safe and it assists in lowering the total operation expenses. IoT enables the creation of a continuous collection, analysis, and transfer of useful energy-related information throughout the grid. This facilitates improved decision-making, real-time monitoring of power use, and performance of the grid. Furthermore, energy management systems based on IoT enable early identification of a malfunction and errors, which is why the electricity supply can be stable and reliable.

authors: Kei Awano, Yoshitsune Sugimura, Yuma Ota, You Wu, Keishi Ogura, Hiroaki Kitaike, Kento Okamura, Shufan Xu, Jin Nakamura, Masaya Kaneko, Yuta Kimura, Hiroaki Nakamura, Ruilin Zhang, Hirofumi Shinohara, Kunyang Liu, Kiichi Niitsu
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper introduces zero stand-by power CMOS image sensor pixel array. The proposed pixel array employs self-oscillating voltage doubler in each pixel, which enables simultaneous energy harvesting and image sensing. The test chip has been designed and developed in 65 nm CMOS. The pixel size is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0736 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. Measured results demonstrated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-\text{Hz}$</tex> operation without any standby pixel power, which shows potential application for thermal-aware zero-stand-by-power imaging.

title: Single—Channel EEG Signal Based Emotion Recognition System Using Quantum Local Binary Pattern
authors: M. Maithri, U. Raghavendra, Anjan Gudigar, Shaunak Geetprasad, Niha Singhania, Akshay B Salian, Samir Kumar Praharaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Recognition of emotion from Electroencephalogram (EEG) signals has become a key area in healthcare and human-computer interaction. The current study introduces a novel method for emotion recognition. Extraction of features from EEG signals is performed using Quantum Local Binary Pattern (QLBP), and further emotions were classified using a Support Vector Machine (SVM). The proposed approach targets single-channel EEG analysis, i.e., T7 channel from the SEED dataset, for classifying emotions into positive, neutral, and negative states. QLBP acquires subtle variations from EEG signals effectively with strong feature representation. Furthermore, the SVM classifier with various kernels, including polynomial, linear, Radial Basis Function, Gaussian, and with different neighbor values, was tested. The linear kernel yielded the maximum average accuracy of 94.5% with two neighbors. The findings highlight the advantages of combining QLBP with SVM to determine its feasibility for implementing an efficient real-world mental state estimation system.

title: Research on Power Grid Data Governance Technology Based on Artificial Intelligence Algorithms
authors: Xia Shangguan, Xiaowan Zeng, Liangbin Dong, Xiaoxi Fu, Jingyi Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The massive amount of multi-source heterogeneous data generated during the operation of the smart grid poses a dual challenge to data governance technology in terms of real-time and domain adaptability. This study proposes a hybrid governance framework based on artificial intelligence algorithms to address the shortcomings of traditional governance methods in dealing with the dynamic characteristics and topological constraints of power grid data. By constructing a three-layer architecture of “ARIMA+CNN+knowledge graph”, the collaboration of time series prediction, anomaly detection, and topology inference is achieved: using ARIMA to capture data stationary features, CNN to extract nonlinear patterns, and knowledge graph embedded in power grid topology rules and business logic, forming an intelligent closed loop of “prediction detection cleaning traceability”. Experiments show that the accuracy rate of the framework in current data anomaly identification reaches 96.3%, the processing delay is stable at 280 ms under <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5000 / \mathrm{s}$</tex> traffic, and the CPU utilization is reduced by more than 30% compared with the single model, effectively solving the problem of multi-source data collaborative governance and real-time response. The research results provide a technical path with both algorithm efficiency and business interpretability for power grid data governance, and will explore the application of federated learning and edge computing in cross domain governance in the future.

title: Innovative Fusion of Blind Chromophore Separation, Artificial Intelligence and Grabcut Algorithm for Skin Disease prediction
authors: Harish Kumar, Anuradha Taluja, Shiva Garg, Pinki Nayak, Vinay Singhal, Vishal Chaudhary
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Skin diseases affect a significant portion of the global population, leading to considerable physical discomfort and psychological distress. It is still hard to make an accurate diagnosis because the symptoms of many different skin diseases are hard to tell apart and seem to be quite similar and, and in severe conditions it is cancerous. Also, the traditional way of doing a visual exam takes a long time and is likely to make mistakes. The goal of this project is to provide a new way to diagnose skin illnesses that uses Blind Chromophore Separation (BCS), Artificial Intelligence (AI), and the GrabCut algorithm. This procedure would be quick, correct, and not hurt at all. The BCS method uses pictures of the skin to get important chromophore information, like the amount of melanin and hemoglobin, which shows how healthy the skin is overall. More particular, convolutional neural networks are used to assess these chromophore-based photos. They achieve this by spotting minute patterns and appropriately categorizing a variety of skin diseases. The GrabCut algorithm also makes lesion segmentation better by making sure that damaged areas are appropriately taken out for future study. The suggested framework offers many benefits, such as improving the accuracy of diagnoses, minimizing the need for expert help, and giving a solution that can be used in real clinical settings. More work will be done in the future to make it easier to find and classify skin disorders earlier. To do this, the dataset will need to be bigger and the AI model will need to be smarter.

title: TabBoost: Combining Tree-Based and Attention-Based Models for Lifestyle Prediction
authors: Hyegang Son, HyungJun Baek, Young Geun Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The growing availability of lifelog data from wearable devices and mobile sensors provides valuable opportunities to predict lifestyle indicators related to health, such as sleep quality, stress, and physical activity. Traditional models like LightGBM perform well on tabular data but rely on handcrafted features and may miss complex temporal dependencies. Deep learning models such as TabNet use attention mechanisms for dynamic feature selection and end-to-end learning but require more computational resources. We propose TabBoost, an ensemble framework combining LightGBM’s efficiency and interpretability with TabNet’s adaptive feature learning. Experiments on real-world lifelog datasets demonstrate that TabBoost consistently outperforms individual baselines, achieving up to 33.40% improvement in key metrics. Our results suggest that integrating complementary strengths of different models can lead to more robust and generalizable performance in lifestyle prediction. Beyond performance gains, TabBoost also provides practical insights for designing efficient and interpretable systems that can be deployed in real-world health monitoring applications.

title: Hierarchical Progressive Fusion: A Complexity-Aware Multimodal Integration Framework for Visual Question Answering
authors: Weidong Tian, Gen Li, Weicheng Zhao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA) requires effective integration of heterogeneous visual and textual information. This paper presents a hierarchical progressive fusion framework that addresses the limitations of existing single-level multimodal fusion approaches. Our key innovation is a multi-level crossmodal attention mechanism that enables simultaneous interaction between visual and textual features at different abstraction levels, coupled with a complexity-aware progressive fusion strategy that adaptively weights multimodal contributions based on question complexity. The framework employs a novel complexity estimation module that analyzes question structure, semantic depth, and reasoning requirements to dynamically adjust fusion weights. Experimental results on VQA v2.0 and GQA datasets demonstrate significant improvements, achieving 82.38% overall closed-domain matching accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(72.56 {\%}$</tex> on complex reasoning and open-ended questions, BLEU- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{6 8. 3} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CIDEr} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{1 2 5. 7} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex>) on VQA v 2.0 and 69.7% (BLEU-4 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=65.2 {\%}$</tex>, CIDEr <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=118.3 {\%}$</tex>) on GQA, outperforming recent generative baselines (e.g., LLaVA-1.5, MiniGPT-4-V2) by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.26 \%-1.86 {\%}$</tex> in accuracy and 3.2%-<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 5 \%}$</tex> in CIDEr. Ablation studies confirm the individual contributions of hierarchical fusion <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(1.23 \%)$</tex>, progressive fusion strategy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(1.08 \%)$</tex>, and complexity-aware weighting (1.15%). The method particularly excels in handling complex reasoning questions, demonstrating the effectiveness of our hierarchical progressive fusion approach.

title: Hydra Radio Access Network (Hydra-RAN): Multi-Functional Communications and Sensing Networks with Hydra Distributed Unit (H-DU) Scalability Optimization
authors: Rafid I. Abd, Kwang Soon Kim, S.R. Mohandes, Eui Whan Jin
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The exponential growth of connected devices and heterogeneous data demands a fundamental shift in radio access network design. This paper introduces the Hydra radio access network (Hydra-RAN), a bio-inspired, multi-functional architecture that unifies sensing, communication, and AI-driven decision-making within an adaptive infrastructure. Central to this framework is the Hydra distributed unit (H-DU), which acts as a cognitive control core to manage dense clusters of sensing and radio units (SRUs). We propose an H-DU scalability optimization framework to ensure low-latency, energy-efficient operation in ultra-dense deployments. Mathematical formulations quantify processing loads, latency, and energy constraints, while simulation results demonstrate significant gains in energy efficiency, spectral efficiency, and scalability over state-of-the-art architectures.

title: Performance Evaluation and Optimization of the Sampling Process of an Neuropredictive SAR ADC
authors: Alexander Spielberger, Lucas Spitzkopf, Albert-Marcel Schrotz, Christof Pfannenmüller, Robert Weigel, Norman Franchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The functionality of the sampling process of a neuropredictive SAR ADC is analyzed and the behavior of the Neuromorphic ADC is modeled in a Python simulation and verified through measurements with different parameters. By checking the boundary values of the prediction window, clock cycles can be saved even if the prediction is incorrect. Simulative modeling enables training of the neural networks close to the hardware. The influence of the prediction window is optimized with the help of the simulation to reduce the conversion time. The maximum cycle saving for a noisy ADC is reduced from 60% to 52% for an 16b ADC with an SNR of 70 dB.

title: Embedded System Design for Heart Condition Identification Based on Signal Characteristics
authors: Genta Gemilang, Winda Astuti, Muhammad Nurul Puji, Retno Indah Pertiwi, Mahmud Iwan Solihin
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Electrocardiogram (ECG) or Electrocardiography is the most popular heart function detection identification. Currently, ECG examinations can only be done in hospitals and require a specialist cardiologist, which is sometimes not available in every local hospital. In this work, the embedded system of heart function identification based on signal characteristic analysis is developed. The Mel frequency Cepstral Coefficient (MFCC) technique is applied as a feature extraction method to analyze the raw heart signal which recorded using stethoscope. The characteristic of the MFCC processing is then analysis and developed. By using MFCC value is then develop the algorithm based on threshold value for heart signal identification. The integrated embedded system which consists of stethoscope, raspberry pi zero 2 w is developed. The OLED used to display the result of the stand-alone system. The proposed system results in good accuracy, since it has high accuracy for heart diseases identification, this result has the same accuracy if compared with machine learning identification result.

title: Implementation of Weighted Moving Average Method for Raw Material Forecasting in Cafe Management System
authors: Daffa Eka Putri, Tika Adilah Mutiara, Hendra Supendar, Wati Erawati, Rahayu Ningsih, Sri Muryani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Advances in information technology are encouraging businesses to manage operations more efficiently, including in the culinary industry, such as cafés. To support this, an integrated cafe management system is needed to help manage operational activities effectively, from raw material management to sales reporting. One of the main challenges is the accurate estimation of raw material requirements to avoid overstocking or understocking. This study aims to develop a web-based café management system equipped with a raw material requirement forecasting feature using the Weighted Moving Average (WMA). This method assigns greater weight to the most recent data to make the forecasting results more adaptive to usage trends. The system was developed using the Laravel framework and includes front-end and back-end features, raw material data management, usage, forecasting, sales, and reporting. The forecasting results show that the system can generate predictions that closely approximate the data patterns used. This system can illustrate the implementation of forecasting methods in raw material management and support an efficient decision-making process in procurement and café operational management.

title: Fast Tunable InP-LNOI DBR Laser at 1550nm
authors: Sara Bassil, Sylvain Boust, Cosimo Calo, Romain Hersent, Hamed Sattari, Ivan Prieto Gonzalez, Homa Zarebidaki, François Duport, Frédéric Van Dijk, Nadege Courjal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: Controlling the tunability of a laser and being able to precisely adjust its emission frequency enables the development of key components for applications ranging from FMCW (Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave) LiDAR to coherent optical communication and widely tunable radio frequency (RF) signal generation. The hybrid integration of III-V materials with low-loss photonic integrated circuits (PICs) enables the realization of 1550 nm extended-cavity single-mode laser. In this work, we present a reflective semi-conductor optical amplifier (RSOA) butt-coupled to an extended distributed Bragg reflector (DBR) in lithium niobate on insulator (LNOI). Lithium niobate (LN) is an asset material because of its electro optic (EO) effect. This laser exhibits a threshold current of 90 mA and a side-mode suppression ratio (SMSR) of at least 35 dB. Leveraging the EO effect in LN, we demonstrate Bragg grating tuning at 3.14 GHz/V. Additionally, we present the RF design of a transmission line on LNOI, outlining the pathway toward a fast tunable Indium Phosphide (InP)-LNOI DBR laser operating at 1550 nm.

abstract: This paper presents a temperature sensor incorporating an RC-filter-based front-end for efficient sensing. A phase-domain delta-sigma modulator (PD-DSM) is utilized to read out the temperature-dependent phase information extracted by the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R C}$</tex> filter. Across a temperature range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-55{}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$125{}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>, the proposed temperature sensor achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3} \boldsymbol{\sigma}$</tex> temperature error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{+ 1. 5} / \mathbf{- 1} {}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> with two-point trimming and piecewise quadratic correction. It attains a resolution FoM of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$232 \text{fJ} \cdot \mathrm{K}^{2}$</tex> and a supply sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.53^{\circ} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{V}$</tex>.

title: Vision Transformer for Sequence-to-Action Networks in Autonomous Driving Control
authors: Emily Jimin Roh, Tae Hoon Lee, Joongheon Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: End-to-end autonomous driving requires robust mapping from sequential visual inputs to control actions. While convolutional neural network (CNN)-based encoders combined with temporal models such as LSTMs have been widely adopted, they are limited in capturing long-range spatial dependencies and global context within visual sequences. This paper introduces a lightweight vision transformer-based sequence-to-action (ViT-S2A) network that integrates a compact ViT encoder with an long short-term memory (LSTM)-based temporal aggregation module to directly predict discrete driving actions. To validate the feasibility of the proposed framework, we construct a synthetic sequence-to-action benchmark, where object trajectories correspond to left, straight, or right movements. Comparative experiments demonstrate that ViT-S2A consistently outperforms a CNN-LSTM baseline in both convergence speed and prediction accuracy, that highlights the effectiveness of global attention in modeling spatiotemporal dependencies. These results indicate that transformer-based architectures offer a promising direction for scalable, data-efficient autonomous driving control models.

title: A Privacy-Preserving and Amount-Flexible Multi-Hop Payment Protocol for Autonomous IoT Resource Scheduling
authors: Wenqi Li, Zuobin Ying, Yibo Bao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) applications and on-demand logistics has fostered crowdsourced delivery systems where dynamic coordination among senders, couriers, and receivers enables efficient lastmile logistics. However, centralized dispatching exposes privacy and reliability risks, including single points of failure and leakage of routing and transaction data. Blockchainbased Payment Channel Networks (PCNs) address these limitations by moving frequent interactions off-chain while maintaining verifiable settlement on-chain. This paper presents a blockchain-anchored privacy-preserving path optimization protocol that supports variable-amount multihop payments over PCNs. By combining Pedersen commitments and lightweight zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs), the protocol verifies transaction correctness without revealing amounts, and employs blind-channel operations to prevent intermediaries from accessing sensitive data. Experimental results show that the proposed scheme achieves strong privacy protection and scalability with low computational cost, making it suitable for blockchain-based IoT delivery environments.

title: A Low-Power PLL with Supply Noise Insensitive VCO in 65nm CMOS
authors: Thinh Tran-Dinh, Minh Nguyen-Quang, Hung Le-Quang, Du Doan-Khanh, Huy Do-Quang, Sang-Gug Lee, Loan Pham-Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: A stable, low-jitter clock is essential for all components in a System-on-Chip <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{SoC})$</tex>. Especially, in Internet-of-Things <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{IoT})$</tex> applications, the clock generator, typically a phase-locked loop (PLL), must not only exhibit low noise and low power consumption but also maintain resilience against power supply disturbances. This paper presents a type-II <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2^{nd}$</tex> order PLL based on a ring voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO), featuring two key enhancements aimed at mitigating power supply noise (PSN) and improving energy efficiency. First, an impulse sensitivity function (ISF) shaping technique is employed to reduce phase noise and minimize power consumption. Second, a resistor is introduced to balance supply sensitivity and further enhance robustness. The proposed VCO achieves a center frequency of 480MHz, phase noise of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-103\text{dBc}/$</tex> Hz at IMHz offset, and frequency error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\triangle f\approx$</tex> 4.17% over a 10% variation in supply voltage. The complete PLL achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-110\text{dBc}/\text{Hz}$</tex> rms noise at 1.2MHz offset, 3ps integrated jitter, and a figure-of-merit (FoM) of −231.7 dB while consuming only 0.75 mW.

title: Enhanced Financial Inclusion with Boosting-Tree Transfer Learning
authors: Varsha Mittal, Khayrilla Kurbonov, Temur Eshchanov, Jabbarov Umarbek, Asadbek Sabirov, Satendra Pratap Singh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Around the world, many people still don’t have access to financial services, and this issue is especially common in countries with lower or moderate incomes where it is difficult for marginalised groups to obtain official financial services. In order to improve predictive modelling for financial inclusion, this work explores the use of cutting-edge machine learning techniques, including boosting-tree transfer learning. The study uses mobile money transaction records and publicly accessible financial survey data, combining behavioural, demographic, and socioeconomic characteristics. Transfer learning is used to adjust models across regions with restricted data availability, whereas gradient boosting decision trees (GBDT) are utilised as the base learners because of their excellent capacity to model nonlinear relationships. The model was tested using stratified kfold cross-validation, and its performance was measured with metrics like area under the ROC curve (AUC), accuracy, precision, recall, and F 1 -score. The outcomes show that boosting-tree transfer learning achieves 90% accuracy and an AUC of 0.92 on test sets, outperforming baseline models like logistic regression and random forests. Crucially, there are few differences across age and gender groups in fairness-aware judgement, which lowers the possibility of algorithmic exclusion. According to the results, boosting-tree transfer learning offers a scalable strategy to promote inclusive financial systems around the world by enhancing predictive accuracy and facilitating equitable decision-making.

title: Towards Accurate Wi-Fi 6E-based Liquid Sensing in a Static Environment
authors: Sunkee Baik, Dongrak Choi, Saewoong Bahk
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: With the emergence of Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) into the 6G standardization roadmap, there is growing interest in using wireless communication technologies for various sensing applications. Although technologies such as mmWave, UWB have been explored for this purpose, Wi-Fi stands out as a cost-effective and widely deployed technology. While previous studies have primarily utilized Wi-Fi 4 and 5, this work investigates the feasibility of liquid sensing using the latest Wi-Fi 6E standard. We use Channel State Information (CSI) to distinguish between different liquids placed along the Line-Of-Sight (LoS) path, and address challenges specific to Wi-Fi 6E equipped with Intel Ax210. Our proposed method improves sensing classification performance by utilizing CSI amplitude for receiver CSI order alignment. Experimental results demonstrate the potential of Wi-Fi 6E for accurate, low-cost liquid sensing in a static environment.

title: Hybrid Dysgraphia Detection Using Transfer Learning and Handcrafted Features
authors: Prateek Sharma, Basant Agarwal, Gyan Singh Yadav
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Dysgraphia presents a significant challenge in education, characterized by difficulties in writing that can impede academic success. Early detection of dysgraphia is vital for intervention, yet traditional diagnostic methods are often subjective and time-consuming. This paper introduces hand-crafted feature extraction along with features extracted using the VGG16 network through transfer learning. The methodology involves the extraction of different features like baseline angle, pen pressure, slant angle, letter size, line spacing, and word spacing along with 8 different features using a pre-trained VGG16 model by applying transfer learning. Finally, a hybrid model is developed by combining handcrafted and VGG16 features. The final feature set is used to train different machine learning methods such as Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machines, and Random Forest for classification. Experimental results show the effectiveness of the proposed hybrid approach in terms of Precision, Recall, F-measure, and Accuracy. The Random Forest outperformed other models, producing an accuracy of 88.9 %. Experimental results show the improvement in the performance of dysgraphia detection using the hybrid method.

title: Cognitive Response Prediction System for Universal XR Metaverse Games
authors: Jong-Sung Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a cognitive response prediction system for universal XR metaverse Games. The proposed system utilizes XR devices, including XR headset, XR controllers, XR eye trackers and XR body trackers to obtain visual-cognitive response data of XR users and exploits these response data to help XR users of different generations and genders to play XR metaverse games without cognitive difficulties. Then, a new deep learning model with multiple transformer layers is trained to learn and predict visual-cognitive response of XR users. The performance of the proposed system is verified with real experiments.

title: A general model for sustainable vehicle fleets battery capacity optimization: Case study on the Italian Fire and Rescue Service Fleet
authors: Diego Ferrazza, Piergiacomo Cancelliere, Fabrizio Marignetti
abstract: This paper develops a methodology to analyse and compare a combustion engine vehicle fleet to an alternative sustainable one, maintaining high efficiency and resilience during specific operations. This work proposes an algorithm that can assist a generic decision-maker in making the challenging choice of transitioning from a standard and well-established traditional mobility to a novel and more sustainable one. The simulation’s statistical analysis results show the effectiveness of electrifying a conventional internal combustion vehicle fleet into an electric and plug-in hybrid electric one. The algorithm was designed, tested, and applied to the Italian National Fire Rescue and Service (Corpo Nazionale dei Vigili del Fuoco – CNVVF). Due to the peculiarities of the institutional activity of the public rescue and safety service of the CNVVF, it is crucial and mandatory to have a tool that can evaluate the effects of replacing traditional mobility while maintaining high efficiency and business continuity. All the analyses were performed using historical data of the fire and rescue service activities of the CNVVF.

title: A Domain-Specific Framework for Priority-Based Modeling and Optimization of Non-Functional Requirements Beyond Binary Constraints
authors: Anirban Bhar, Sabnam Sengupta, Sankhayan Choudhury, Suchismita Maiti, Shubhendu Banerjee, Suparna Dasgupta, Soumyabrata Saha, Tanusree Saha, Amrut Ranjan Jena, Soumya Bhattacharyya
abstract: Non-Functional Requirements (NFRs) such as performance, security, reliability, and usability significantly influence the overall quality of software systems. However, traditional NFR engineering approaches commonly treat these requirements as binary constraints, i.e., either fully satisfied or not, which limits systematic trade-off reasoning even in conventional single-system software architectures. This limitation becomes critical in complex, dynamic domains such as IoT and cyber-physical systems, where multiple interdependent NFRs must coexist without degrading system performance. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a domain-specific framework for modeling and optimizing priority-based NFRs beyond binary constraints. The framework integrates standard well-recognized quality models like ISO/IEC 25010 and FURPS+, to identify domain-specific NFRs, which are then modeled as soft goals with graded degrees of satisfaction. Priority weights, utility-based reasoning, and multi-objective optimization are integrated to manage conflicts and trade-offs among competing NFRs while preserving system stability. Unlike traditional approaches that enforce a rigidly defined subset of NFRs, the proposed framework enables the combination of multiple NFRs proportionally according to their priority and contextual relevance. The framework is applicable to diverse software-intensive systems including IoT, cloud platforms, healthcare systems, and cyber-physical environments. This work contributes a systematic, scalable, and adaptive approach to proactive NFR management suitable for modern software systems. The concrete research problem addressed is the failure of binary NFR handling in dynamic adaptation settings, leading to over-constrained designs or degraded quality. The framework guarantees improved global utility (15-25% in simulations) and adaptation success (>90%) while maintaining performance thresholds, with low runtime overhead (~O(n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) for n NFRs).

title: CRBP: A Benchmark Dataset of Color-Rendered 3-D-to-2.5-D Facial Projections_supp1-3624674.pdf
authors: Sahil Sharma
abstract: The Colour-Rendered Bosphorus Projections (CRBP) Face dataset overcomes key limitations in 3-D facial analysis by offering a photometrically normalized, multiview dataset specifically tailored for 2.5-D modeling. CRBP utilizes the Bosphorus 3D Face Database, reconstructing textured 3-D meshes for each individual and producing six canonical 2-D projections. To improve model compatibility and minimize background noise, each projection is processed using YOLOv8 for face detection. This results in two organized subsets, namely, CRBP-Raw (full scene) and CRBP-YOLOv8 (face-cropped). This dual-format design facilitates thorough benchmarking of pose-invariant, occlusion-resilient, and expression-aware models within a convolutional neural network-compatible image space. Dataset statistics indicate that YOLOv8 enhances facial alignment, however, it also introduces sample selection bias, especially in extreme yaw and occlusion scenarios. CRBP facilitates applications in emotion recognition, biometric authentication, and avatar creation. The dataset is available at: https://dx.doi.org/10.21227/4qns-ys45.
